metadata.title: Characterising within-hospital SARS-CoV-2 transmission events using epidemiological and viral genomic data across two pandemic waves

body_text.text: transmission pairs with a Poisson distribution; this places less likelihood weight on the genetic sequence data than the original formulation and allows a more evenly weighted integration with ward data. By modelling mutation events as a feature of infection, assuming no within-host diversity and using a per-infectious-generation, per-base mutation rate (.) and number of comparable nucleotides 2(3 ! , 3 ' ! ), the genetic likelihood + ! $ of the SNP distance 4(3 ! , 3 ' ! )between the samples of a case i and its most recently sampled ancestor 5 ! separated by 6 ! generations is given by:
The mutation rate (.) represents a probability and was assigned a Beta distributed prior (Supplementary Table 1 ).

Though the infectious process is unobserved, the probability of transmission between cases can be estimated from the ward data, more specifically from the pair of wards they are registered in on the most likely inferred day of infection (Supplementary Fig. 5 ). We assume that infection is more likely to occur between individuals on the same ward and model this assumption explicitly by defining the parameter 0 as the probability of a primary case infecting a secondary case registered on the same ward on the day of infection, conditional on the primary case having caused an infection. We refer to such events as "within-ward" infections.
The probability of a primary case infecting a secondary case registered on a different ward on the day of infection is therefore 1 − 0, which we refer to as "between-ward" infections.

This accounts for uncertainty in using ward data to estimate the infectious process, for example if a patient visits another ward during their stay in the hospital or if viral particles are transferred between wards via contaminated equipment or ventilation. However, 1 − 0 defines the marginal probability of transmission pairs being registered on any two different wards, while the ward likelihood must consider the probability of infection occurring between the two specific wards where the transmission pair is based.

To calculate this probability, the "connectedness" of all wards in the hospital must be defined, in other words the probability of infection moving from a given ward to any other given ward. Formally, given @ + different wards in the hospital, we define a transition matrix A (@ + × @ + ), with individual elements A ,,. describing the probability of a case registered in ward k infecting a case registered in ward l; these probabilities are conditional on a between-ward infection, which occurs with probability1 − 0 as defined above. The rows of this matrix therefore sum to 1, under the assumption that all outgoing infections occur in one of the other wards, and A ,,, = 0. Given that we lacked information on the "connectedness" of wards (for example as given by proximity the number or staff shared between them), we made the neutral assumption that infection occurs with equal probability to any other ward such that A ,,. = 1/(@ + − 1).

We then combine the probability of infection occurring within or between wards (as given by 0) with information on the "connectedness" of wards (as given by the transition matrix A) to define a matrix X as a function of 0 as follows:

where individual elements D(0) [F, 2] describe the probability of a case in ward k infecting a case in ward l, conditional on the primary case having caused an infection. In other words, this matrix describes the expected proportion of infections originating in ward k that end up in ward l; the diagonal elements represent within-ward infections, which simply occur with probability 0, while the non-diagonal elements represent between-ward infections, which occur with the probability of a between-ward infection (1 − 0) multiplied by the "connectedness" of those two wards (A ,,. ). Using the ward designation of 0 to indicate a case not being registered in the hospital, we assume that infection can only occur between Fig. 5 ). As cases tend to remain on a single ward for a given period of time, these ward states cannot be considered independent. We therefore condition the later ward state on the earlier ward state by defining a parameter 1 as the daily probability of a case being registered on the same ward it was in on the day of infection. If the case is found on a different ward, the specific probability of being transferred from a given ward k to a different ward l is calculated using the same transition probability A ,,. defined above.

We therefore assume that ward transfers of unobserved infections follow the same transition probabilities as infections occurring between wards, though this assumption could be easily relaxed if the necessary data to inform these estimates were available. We then define a matrix Y as a function of 1: This recursive approach can be initialised as the ward states of the most recent sampled ancestor 5 ! are observed. The probability of the first unobserved individual becoming infected on any given ward i, given its infector 5 ! is registered in the observed ward k on the day of onward infection, is simply given by D(0) [F, 2] . We therefore define a matrix Z as a function of 0, 1 and 6:
where × indicates the matrix multiplication operator and ^ the exponentiation operator.

The first term calculates the probability of movement of infection from the sampled ancestor 5 ! to the first unobserved infection, while the exponentiated term accounts for successive unobserved generations of infection. Individual elements N(0, 1, 6 ! ) [F, 2] therefore describe the probability of infection originating in a given ward k and ending up on ward l after 6 ! generations of infection.
Given these probabilities, the ward likelihood + ! 4 can then be defined for a given case i as:
and calculated as:

The ward likelihood therefore describes the probability of infection originating in the ward that 5 ! is registered in on the day of onward infection (H ! !02 if 6 ! = 1 or H ! /01 if 6 ! > 1), and ending up in the ward that i is registered in on its day of infection (H ! !02 ) after 6 ! generations of infection.
All COVID positive cases in patients were classified in 5 groups as in 3 :
(1) Community-Onset Community-Associated: Positive specimen date up to 14 days before, or within 2 days after, hospital admission, with no discharge from hospital in 14 days before specimen date.

(2) Community-Onset Suspected Healthcare-Associated: Positive specimen date up to 14 days before, or within 2 days after, hospital admission, with discharge from hospital in 14 days before specimen date.

(3) Hospital-Onset Suspected Healthcare-Associated: Positive specimen dated 8-14 days after hospital admission; or specimen date 3-14 days after admission, with discharge from hospital in 14 days before specimen date.
(4) Hospital-Onset Intermediate Healthcare-Associated: Positive specimen date 3-7 days after hospital admission, with no discharge from hospital in 14 days before specimen date.
(5) Hospital-Onset Healthcare-Associated: Positive specimen date to 15 or more days after hospital admission.

The ascertainment parameter, π, was estimated by combining (i) the proportion of known cases which have high quality sequence, (ii) the proportion of these cases where their location is known and (iii) the proportion of cases which are detected. While the first two of these proportions were known, the third was more uncertain. were classified into a 'not admitted' category, with those who required admission stratified into the six categories listed above. All negative delays were removed from these 13 distributions. Next, for each individual for whom a date of onset was not recorded, we randomly sampled a delay between onset and testing from the respective known distributions associated with each infection category and individual type (staff or inpatient).

If a distribution was unable to be defined due to absence of data, we instead sampled from the undefined patient or staff category. Finally, we calculated the imputed onset date of individuals with a sampled delay between symptom onset to testing by subtracting the sample delay from the recorded date of testing.

The precise proportion of imported cases was unknown and this uncertainty was captured as part of the final global sensitivity analysis. The proportion of imported patient cases was estimated from the admission date, symptom onset date and the incubation period. As we were unable to accurately estimate the proportion of imports for staff the sampling distributions outlined below include a staff import proportion ranging from 0% to 100%. The rationale for the Wave 1 and Wave 2 import proportions are outlined below.

The estimated import proportion for patients in Wave 1 was 85% (~660/780; 95% confidence interval: 82% -87%). Combining the inpatient and staff estimate (261/522, 50%) gives an estimated import percentage of ~68% (885/1302). Considering both extreme scenarios of no staff being imports and all staff being imports gives a range in the import percentage of ~48% to ~88%. To account for this uncertainty in the final results the import proportion for Wave 1 is varied 500 times, sampling from a normal distribution with mean 0.7 and standard deviation 0.075.
Combining the patient (77%, ~439/580; 95% confidence interval: 73% -80%) and staff (150/299, 50%) estimate gives an estimated import percentage of ~59% (515/879).
Considering both extreme scenarios as above gives a range of ~42% to ~76%. The import proportion for wave 2 is sampled from the normal distribution with mean 0.6 and standard deviation 0.06.

The Outbreaker2 model requires the number of imports (i.e. community-associated infections) to be known in advance. Here, we relaxed this assumption by integrating over the distribution of the number of imports in independent MCMC chains, for each of which the number of imports was randomly drawn from a binomial distribution with N trials and a probability drawn from a Beta distribution (see proportion of imported cases section below).

We define N as the total number of cases in the dataset, and the mean of the Beta distribution (p) as the probability across all cases that they are community-acquired. We first calculated, for each patient, i, the probability of observing the delay between their admission and their symptom onset, W ! , given their infection was community-acquired, as the probability that their incubation period, randomly sampled from the known incubation period distribution, was longer than their delay between admission and symptom onset, "(W ! | X$ ! ). We then calculated for each individual, i, the probability that their infection was community-acquired given the delay between admission and symptom onset, as
where the prior probability "(X$) was assumed to be 0.9 5 and "(Z$) − 1 − "(X$) and

We then calculated the average patient-specific probability of a community-acquired infection as the mean of "(X$ ! | W ! ) across all individuals. As admission data are unavailable for staff, we set bounds for the fraction of staff who acquired infection in the community as between 0 and 1. We then calculated the fraction of community-acquired infections across the whole dataset as the weighted sum of the patient-specific and the staff-specific probabilities as described in the proportion of imported cases section above.

To assign the identity of the imports, we calculated the mean individual likelihood + ! = iterations). For each MCMC chain in the main analysis, the randomly drawn number of imports were randomly assigned identities using the inverse of the individual likelihood + ! .

Outbreaker was run in parallel integrating across uncertainty in the symptom onset data and the number and identity of imports. Specifically, we used a global sensitivity analysis in our base case analysis via an ensemble approach in which we generated a total of 10,000 posterior transmission networks. These 10,000 samples were generated from a sample of 100 imputed symptom onset datasets. In addition, we drew five samples of the number and identity of imports and ran an MCMC across all 500 combinations. We then sampled 20 posterior networks from each of the converged chains of these 500 MCMC runs. Each parallel MCMC chain was run for 1100 iterations with a thinning frequency of 1/50 and a burn-in of 100 iterations. We ran the analysis using a timescale of quarter-day increments consistent with the ward location data being available to the nearest 6-hour interval.

FIGREF0.text: cases in the hospital by defining D(0)[F, 2] = 0 if F = 0 or 2 = 0. This completes the ward likelihood for direct transmission pairs (Supplementary Fig. 5), which describes the probability of a primary case on ward k infecting a secondary case on ward l on the day of infection of the secondary case and is given by D(0)[F, 2]. To extend this model to account for unobserved infections, we analytically integrate over potential ward states (the unobserved ward of an unobserved infection on a given day) in a manner similar to the convolution over possible infection times of unobserved infections used in the generation time likelihood + ! # . Formally, we calculate the probability of the most recent sampled ancestor 5 ! , registered on a given ward k, causing infection in case i, registered on a given ward l, after 6 ! generations of infection. This approach requires knowledge of the ward of 5 ! on the day the unobserved chain of infections leading to case i begins, which in turn requires knowledge of the time of infection of the first unobserved infection between 5 ! and i (Supplementary Fig. 5). Infection times of later cases in the unobserved transmission chain are not required as these infection events are not linked to either of the observed cases 5 ! or i and therefore do not feature in the ward likelihood. As the default Outbreaker model does not impute infection times of unobserved infections, we extended the model to impute an additional set of augmented data H ! /01 , called the ancestral infection time and defined as the infection time of the earliest unobserved infection in an unobserved transmission chain separating 5 ! and i.

FIGREF1.text: the probability of an unobserved infection being transferred from a given ward k on the day of infection to a given ward l on the day of onward infection. Given this parameterization it is possible to integrate over the unobserved transmission pathways linking a given ward k to a given ward l over 6 ! generations of infection. We do so by first defining all potential transmission routes between any two wards in a single unobserved generation of infection (Supplementary Fig. 6). Fast integration over these transmission routes that accounts for all combinations of ward transfers and infection events can be achieved by matrix multiplication of J(1) and D(0) such that the elements of J(1) × D(0) describe the probability of an unobserved individual that was infected on ward k causing infection on ward l after one unobserved generation of infection.The probability of each route(Supplementary Fig. 6)is conditional on the primary case becoming infected on that given ward in the previous generation of infection. The matrix product J(1) × D(0) can therefore be multiplied by itself in a recursive manner to integrate over transmission pathways for greater numbers of unobserved infections, where each multiplication by J(1) × D(0) represents the movement of infection in one unobserved generation.

FIGREF3.text: simulations calculate a posterior sample of the distribution of the number of observed secondary cases by evaluating, for each case, the total number of connected cases (either direct transmission or with intermediate unsampled individuals). Thus, our model captures 'observed' secondary cases which are either themselves detected, or whose own descendants of transmission are detected. In contrast, unobserved secondary infections are those which are not detected by the model. These infections are unobserved because both they and their descendants are undetected by the model. To calculate the true number of secondary cases (Z), including both observed and unobserved, calculate the unconditional probability distribution of true cases using the expression: "(N = [) = ∑ !67 "(N = [ | D = :)"(D = :). Circles represent infection times, triangles dates of symptom onset, squares dates of onward infection. Red curved lines indicate the generation time distribution. (B) A case i and its most recent sampled ancestor! ! are separated by an unobserved infection. The ancestral infection time " ! Black circles represent the ward the primary case is infected on. Black squares represent the ward of the primary case on the day of onward infection.
